hints.content:
### Creating the mapping diagram

Pairing the elements in the diagram according to the table should result in a diagram that looks like this:

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6992ab21595beb3fdc3c89d99365e80000ca1cd7.png)

### Determining whether $f$ is invertible

If $f$ maps $x$ to $y$, then $f^{-1}$ maps $y$ to $x$. We can look at the reverse direction of the mapping and see if the result represents a function from the set on the right to the set on the left.

$\qquad$![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4529def796908afdc00db6bdc493e6297a88c11c.png)

Functions can only have one unique output for each input. Since the input $\green {-6}$ maps to  $\purple a$, $\purple c$, and $\purple e$, this diagram does not represent a function and $f^{-1}$ does not exist.

### The answers

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6992ab21595beb3fdc3c89d99365e80000ca1cd7.png)

$f$ is *not* invertible

question.content:
$f$ is a finite function whose domain is the letters $a$ to $e$. The following table lists the output for each input in $f$'s domain.

$x$|$a$|$b$|$c$|$d$|$e$
:-|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:
$f(x)$|$-6$|$3$|$-6$|$2$|$-6$

**Build the mapping diagram for $f$ by dragging the endpoints of the segments in the graph below so that they pair each domain element with its correct range element. **

**Then, determine if $f$ is invertible.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

[[☃ radio 1]]

If $f$ maps $x$ to $y$, then $f^{-1}$ maps $y$ to $x$. We can look at the reverse direction of the mapping and see if the result represents a function from the set on the right to the set on the left.

$f$ is invertible
